text: `f(a=b)` is still just a “sugar” for `f("a", b)`, no?

Yeah, “real” was a generous choice of words. More than anything, it’s just nice that when you’re calling a function, you can now have a clearer distinction between passing in positional argument strings and keyword arguments. It always made it hard to read code when you see a bunch of strings as arguments and you have to figure out which of those are supposed to be parts of key-value pairs and which are positional arguments that just happen to be strings.

elements.text: Yeah, “real” was a generous choice of words. More than anything, it’s just nice that when you’re calling a function, you can now have a clearer distinction between passing in positional argument strings and keyword arguments. It always made it hard to read code when you see a bunch of strings as arguments and you have to figure out which of those are supposed to be parts of key-value pairs and which are positional arguments that just happen to be strings.

text: Oh well. String arguments was what pushed me to run, not walk, to another language and found Julia.

elements.text: Oh well. String arguments was what pushed me to run, not walk, to another language and found Julia.

text: Wait, do you still have to implement the handling inside the function manually?

elements.text: Wait, do you still have to implement the handling inside the function manually?

text: There is an `arguments` block now... which is still a pretty clunky way of handling it. But it’s better than what was there before, I guess.
